STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
March 15, 2024
Cathey Prudhomme
Eagle Village, Inc.
4507 170th Ave,
Hersey, MI, 49639-8785
Re: License #: CB670201101
Dear Cathey Prudhomme:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
March 7, 2024. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective
action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this
letter and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Samantha Way, at (517) 243-9743.
Sincerely,
Melinda Gubbins, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
701 S. Elmwood, Ste. 11
Traverse City, MI 49684
(231) 342-3721
enclosure
2

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
INTERIM INSPECTION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CB670201101
Licensee Group Organization: Eagle Village Inc
Licensee Designee: Cathey Prudhomme
Chief Administrator: Cathey Prudhomme
Name of Agency: Eagle Village, Inc.
Agency Address: 4507 170th Ave
Hersey, MI 49639-8785
Agency Telephone #: 2318322234
Original Issuance Date: 03/24/1993
Service Types: Place children for adoption, Certify foster
homes for license, Supervise Independent
Living, Place children in foster home,
Evaluate Applicants for adoption
1

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CPA Rule 400.12327 Special evaluation
• (5) Within 15 days of the conclusion of the
evaluation, an agency shall complete a written
report.
One of three special evaluations reviewed did not have a report completed within 15
days of the conclusion of the investigation.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
3/1/2023 RENEWAL, CAP approved 3/16/2023
CPA Rule 400.12327 Special evaluation
• (5) Within 15 days of the conclusion of the
evaluation, an agency shall complete a written
report that includes all the following information:
• (d) Findings of fact, based upon the
evaluation.
One of three special evaluations reviewed did not contain accurate findings of fact,
based on the information gathered.
2

CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans
• (2) An agency shall complete written service plans
for each child and parent or parents, as follows:
• (b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial
removal and at least once every 90
calendar days thereafter.
One of three foster care files reviewed (2 of 11 service plans) did not have the
Updated Service Plan completed timely.
CPA Rule 400.12510 Independent living agreement
• (2) The agreement must be signed and dated by
the youth and the social service worker. The
agreement must be reviewed with the youth at
least once every 90 calendar days and a copy
provided to the youth.
Two of three independent living files reviewed did not contain documentation the
independent living contract was updated and provided to the youth quarterly as
required.
FOM 722-06B Family Team Meeting
FTM’s must occur within the required time frames as
outlined in the following tables:
Case Plan Development/Reassessment
Initial Case Plan (ISP) – within 30 calendar days before
the case plan due date.
Updated Case Plan (USP) – within 30 calendar days
before the case plan due date.
Permanent Ward Service Plan (PWSP) – within 30
calendar days before the case plan due date.
Placement Preservation/Disruption
At least three business days prior to a planned change of
placement or no later than three business days after an
unplanned placement change.
3

Planned and unplanned placement changes include
reunification, placement in a residential setting,
stepdown from a residential or hospital setting, return
from AWOLP, or request for change in foster
home/relative placements.
One of three independent living files reviewed did not have an FTM completed for a
USP.
FOM 722-08D Treatment Plans
When completed, obtain all signatures as appropriate,
including those of parent(s)/guardian(s), foster care
worker, supervisor, foster parent, caregiver, any youth
aged 14 and older and in the case of placement agency
foster care cases, the local DHS office designee.
The caseworker must obtain signatures from all
applicable individuals and upload the signature pages
into the electronic case record within 30 days of the
report date.
One of three foster care files reviewed (1 of 11 service plans) did not obtain the
foster parent’s signature on the parent agency treatment plan (PATP) timely.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• All signatures on PATP's need to be dated.
• Agency should consider uploading list of foster home licensing documents
provided, reviewed and signed by foster parents during renewal visit instead
of uploading each document separately.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
• The facility did not request or require consultation.
4

VI. EVALUATION OF PERIOD UNDER REVIEW
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows. The
agency submitted an acceptable corrective action plan in response to the renewal
inspection completed on 3/1/2023 with a corrective action plan approved on
3/16/2023. During the 2023 review the agency had three violations: R 400.12327
(5) Special evaluation, FOM 722-06B FTM Documentation and FOM 801-03
Medical passports. One of the citations found during this year’s inspection was a
repeat from the 2023 renewal (R 400.12327 (5) Special evaluation). During this
period under review the agency noted there were no barriers to achieving overall
compliance, however as noted, there is a repeat violation. Therefore, the agency
will need to address why the prior corrective action plan did not result in
compliance for that rule.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The assessment reported the agency did not experience any difficulty in meeting
requirements during this review period. The Chief Administrator (CA) stated the
CAP submitted during the last inspection was able to be implemented with no
issues and the impact on the agency was positive.
The CA reported the agency utilizes several tools including MMR, Book of
Business and Info View reports in order to drill down and assess what areas of
improvement are needed. The metrics are also reviewed during supervision
meetings with staff. The CA expressed confidence the agency will continue to
improve over the next review period.
Financial Overview
Financial records were reviewed and there were no concerns identified.
Staff Interviews
Interviews were conducted with two staff via telephone. Staff reported supervisors
meet with them regularly and coworkers are available as needed if issues arise.
Staff reported feeling supported by the agency personally and professionally and
had no concerns.
5

Description of Agency Walk Through
The agency maintains sufficient office space, equipment and supplies to ensure
delivery of foster care, licensing and adoption services. Records are stored
securely.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
The DCWL Agency Analyst identified the following safety concerns:
Safety Alert #1: Relative caregivers did not have their guns stored properly.
Resolution: Agency provided photos to verify that all guns are now stored properly
and have trigger locks as required.
Safety Alert #2: Licensed foster home was observed to have an unscreened
window, unfinished flooring, missing drywall, hole in a wall and foster youth's
bedroom door was broken.
Resolution: The agency provided photos to verify the broken bedroom was
replaced, hole in the wall was patched, missing drywall was repaired, unfinished
flooring was completed, and screws inserted on windows, so the top pane without a
screen is inoperable.
Safety Alert #3: A lock was observed on the outside of a bedroom door in a
licensed foster home.
Resolution: The agency provided photos to verify the lock has been removed. A
special evaluation was also initiated.
Safety Alert #4: Licensed foster home had door alarms that were not in working
order as well as guns that were not properly stored.
Resolution: The agency verified the foster family purchased cable trigger locks and
a case for the bow. A special evaluation was initiated. The agency followed up with
the foster family to ensure the items were received and all guns and bows are now
properly stored.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
6
